notes: Pen-and-ink schoolgirl satire from the St Trinian’s series.

title: Molesworth (book illustrations)
notes: Spiky pen drawings for Geoffrey Willans’s Nigel Molesworth books.

title: New Yorker Cover (example of line wit)
notes: Airy, elegant pen line with dry humor akin to Steinberg.

title: Village Voice Cartoon (early strip)
notes: Loose, talky ink line; psychological/social satire.

title: New Yorker Cartoon (mother & child, representative)
notes: Expressive ink line; humane, wry observation.

title: Addams Family cartoon (representative panel)
notes: Clean pen line with macabre twist; iconic New Yorker style.

title: The Three Robbers (plate illustration)
notes: Graphic, economical line and shapes; darkly playful.

title: The Giving Tree (interior drawing)
notes: Minimal pen line; whimsical-poignant clarity.

title: Ink drawing (mid-century social commentary)
notes: Calligraphic line used for moral/poetic impact.

title: Illustration for Le Locataire (The Tenant)
notes: Surreal, nervous ink line; psychologically charged.

title: Job Cigarettes Poster
notes: Art Nouveau masterpiece featuring a woman with flowing hair and ornate patterns.

title: La Goulue at the Moulin Rouge
notes: Bold lithograph capturing the nightlife of Paris; iconic for poster art history.

title: Absinthe Robette
notes: Graceful woman raising a glass of absinthe; flowing Art Nouveau design.

title: Lait pur Stérilisé de la Vingeanne
notes: Warm domestic scene promoting sterilized milk; early modern advertising charm.

title: Cachou Lajaunie
notes: Early example of bold color and character-driven advertising.

title: Bitter Campari
notes: Bright, surreal imagery; established Campari’s visual identity.

title: Chocolat Menier
notes: Features the famous little girl writing on a wall; family-friendly branding icon.

title: Dubonnet Aperitif
notes: Modernist triptych showing evolution of enjoying Dubonnet; witty visual narrative.

title: Normandie Ocean Liner Poster
notes: Streamlined Art Deco depiction of the French ocean liner; symbol of luxury and progress.

title: Drink Coca-Cola
notes: Introduced the jolly red-suited Santa Claus; key in shaping modern holiday imagery.

title: Air France – L’Afrique
notes: Dreamlike map-style travel poster; elegant, cartographic surrealism.

title: The Uncle Sam \'I Want You\' Poster
notes: Iconic U.S. recruitment poster; became a global symbol of patriotism.

title: Keep Calm and Carry On
notes: Wartime morale booster rediscovered decades later as a cultural meme.

title: Rosie the Riveter – We Can Do It!
notes: Empowering WWII poster encouraging women to join the workforce.

title: Drink Guinness for Strength
notes: Whimsical poster series featuring animals; playful and humorous branding.

title: See America – WPA Travel Poster
notes: Stylized national park travel poster from New Deal-era public art.

title: Pan American Airways – South America
notes: Bold geometric composition promoting air travel modernism.

title: Orangina Poster
notes: Minimalist curves and orange hues; classic postwar French design.

title: Vespa Scooter Poster
notes: Stylish depiction of Italian postwar optimism and mobility.

title: Perrier – C’est Fou!
notes: Playful, sensual composition; continuation of Villemot’s sleek style.

title: Côte d’Azur Pullman Express
notes: Train poster emphasizing speed and luxury with streamlined, geometric design.

title: Visit Spain – Iberia Airlines
notes: Vivid travel poster capturing Spain’s warmth and Mediterranean sunlight through Deco stylization.

title: Chicago World\'s Fair – A Century of Progress
notes: Dynamic modernist composition celebrating technological progress and architecture.

title: Fly TWA to New York
notes: Technicolor depiction of New York skyline with jazz-age energy; bridge between Deco and Mid-century design.

title: Cunard Line to New York
notes: Strong vertical composition of ocean liner funnels; classic maritime Deco.

title: Egypt Travel Poster
notes: Modernist rendering of the Sphinx and pyramids with simplified geometry and radiant desert tones.

title: Southampton – Gateway to the World
notes: British Art Deco poster featuring elegant ships and coastal vistas; created for Southern Railway.

title: See America – WPA National Parks Poster
notes: Stylized, serene landscapes; Deco-influenced simplification of natural forms.

title: Drink Coca-Cola
notes: Sunny, wholesome scene of a woman enjoying Coke; bright colors and idealized realism typical of 1950s advertising.

title: Volkswagen Beetle – Think Small
notes: Minimalist ad campaign that revolutionized marketing; witty and clean composition.

title: Lucky Strike – It\'s Toasted
notes: Bold industrial design aesthetic paired with sleek typography by Loewy, the father of streamlining.

title: Perrier – C’est Fou!
notes: Elegant, curvilinear design with playful sophistication; hallmark of Villemot’s minimalism.

title: Vespa Scooter Poster
notes: Stylish depiction of Italian freedom and postwar optimism; bright and breezy composition.

title: General Electric – Progress Is Our Most Important Product
notes: Classic corporate optimism; glowing atomic-age imagery symbolizing innovation.

title: Pan Am – Fly to Europe
notes: Vibrant travel poster showing European landmarks; bold color fields and simplified silhouettes.

title: Chanel No.5 Advertisement
notes: Luxurious minimalism with golden highlights; defined mid-century glamour marketing.

title: Pepsi – The Light Refreshment
notes: Fresh-faced models and patriotic palette; youthful energy emblematic of 1950s consumerism.

title: Campbell’s Soup – Homemaker’s Favorite
notes: Idealized domestic scene featuring the Campbell Kids; warm colors and cheerful realism.

title: Shell Motor Spirit – British Quality
notes: Cubist-inspired poster blending industry and nature; bold angles, Shell’s famous yellow and red branding.

title: Bovril – Gives Strength
notes: Quaint Edwardian-era illustration emphasizing vitality; iconic bull imagery for Bovril’s beef extract.

title: Michelin Man (Bibendum)
notes: One of the first brand mascots in advertising; humorous depiction of Bibendum made from tires.

title: General Motors – Futurama Exhibit
notes: Created for the New York World’s Fair; visionary ad for the future of mobility and design.

title: Ford V8 – Streamlined Power
notes: Art Deco automotive poster showing speed and aerodynamic style; chrome and motion emphasized.

title: Electrolux – Servant to the Home
notes: Mid-century industrial optimism; promotes domestic convenience and modern design.

title: Kodak – The Brownie Camera
notes: Early consumer photography ad showing families capturing leisure moments; simple, wholesome imagery.

title: Texaco – The Star of the American Road
notes: Patriotic palette and sleek cars; emblematic of postwar American automotive freedom.

title: DuPont – Better Things for Better Living
notes: Industrial design advertising emphasizing chemistry as a source of progress; atomic-age optimism.

title: Westinghouse – We Can Do It!
notes: Industrial morale poster that became a feminist symbol; created for factory workers during WWII.

title: Boeing – The Jet Age Begins
notes: Streamlined jet profile with glowing contrails; celebrating the dawn of commercial air travel.

title: Pan American World Airways – The World Is Smaller
notes: Clean global motif connecting cities by lines; minimalistic early corporate internationalism.

title: IBM – Think
notes: Corporate modernism distilled; visual wit and minimal typography defining mid-century branding.

title: Esso – Happy Motoring!
notes: Playful cartoon mascots and bright roadside palette; cheerful postwar consumerism.

title: Frigidaire – The Modern Kitchen
notes: Idealized domestic life; chrome appliances and atomic-age typography.

title: Philco Television – The Window to the World
notes: Celebrates the television as a family centerpiece; glowing screens and futuristic motifs.

title: Cinzano Vermouth
notes: Joyous composition with prancing zebra; one of Cappiello’s most famous dynamic poster designs.

title: General Electric – Lighting the Future
notes: Electric light as a symbol of progress; radiant, industrial optimism of the interwar period.

title: Air France – Le Monde Entier
notes: Celestial map of Air France routes; dreamlike and sophisticated travel branding.

title: Evinrude Outboard Motors
notes: Family boating adventure rendered in bold realism; conveys freedom and leisure.

title: The Conquest of Space (book illustrations)
notes: Highly detailed planetary vistas and spacecraft designs that defined mid-century space realism.

title: Astounding Science Fiction – May 1941 Cover
notes: Elegant depiction of spacemen and sleek rockets; refined realism unusual for pulp art.

title: Amazing Stories – January 1940 Cover
notes: Classic pulp imagery with metallic robots and radiant sci-fi heroines.

title: Thrilling Wonder Stories – August 1943
notes: Glossy pulp composition featuring ray guns and bubble helmets; archetypal \'space opera\' aesthetic.

title: Startling Stories – September 1944
notes: Futuristic female astronaut imagery that inspired decades of sci-fi pulp tropes.

title: If the Stars Are Gods (concept sketch)
notes: Atmospheric cosmic scene imagining interplanetary travel; early space art realism.

title: Rocket Ship X-M Poster Art
notes: Retro-futuristic spacecraft and astronauts; cinematic sci-fi pulp aesthetic.

title: Worlds Beyond Magazine – December 1949
notes: Atmospheric alien landscapes and surreal planetscapes; transitional to the 1950s sci-fi realism.

title: Science Fiction Quarterly – Spring 1942
notes: Vivid, technical depiction of futuristic cities and giant robots; foundational work in sci-fi visualization.

title: Fantastic Adventures – June 1940
notes: Colorful fantasy-meets-science cover art; exotic planets and advanced civilizations.

title: Mechanix Illustrated – The Home of Tomorrow
notes: Streamlined chrome utopia with flying cars and automated homes; proto–Jetsons aesthetic.

title: Popular Mechanics – City of the Future
notes: Illustration of futuristic skyscrapers, highways, and airships; wartime optimism meets urban futurism.

title: Science Illustrated – Atomic Age Issue
notes: Spectacular fusion of science and imagination; rocket bases and nuclear-powered cities.

title: Air Trails Pictorial – Rocket Plane Concept
notes: Sleek silver rocket aircraft cruising above futuristic skylines; early atomic-age aesthetic.

title: Amazing Stories – August 1947
notes: Alien creatures rendered in neon color with pulsing energy weapons; pulp futurism at its peak.

title: The Rocket and the Future (Popular Science cover)
notes: Postwar optimism through imagery of V-2–inspired space travel; science as salvation theme.

title: Science Fiction Stories – September 1949
notes: Vibrant surrealism; merging biological and mechanical motifs in futuristic forms.

title: The Future City – GM Futurama Exhibit Concept
notes: Urban utopia of highways, monorails, and towers; precursor to 1950s techno-optimism.

title: Air Wonder Stories – Futuristic Airship
notes: Massive orbital airship hovering above futuristic city; classic retro-futurist aesthetic.

title: Rocket to the Moon Concept Art
notes: Scientific yet romantic vision of lunar travel; influenced early NASA visualizations.

Coalbrookdale by Night
citation: Depicts the Bedlam Furnaces at Coalbrookdale, symbolizing the birth of the Industrial Revolution in Ironbridge Gorge, England.

title: An Iron Forge
citation: Early industrial scene showing a water-powered forge and ironworkers, emphasizing light and machinery.

title: Progress (The Advance of Civilization)
citation: Allegorical landscape showing locomotives, telegraph poles, and westward expansion as symbols of industrial progress.

title: A Country Blacksmith (Disputing upon the Price of Iron)
citation: Depicts a rural forge, blending traditional craftsmanship with emerging industrial themes.

title: Allegory of Industry
citation: Shows women working at spinning wheels, representing the spirit of industrial labor and production.

title: Factories at Asnières (Seen from the Quai de Clichy)
citation: Impressionist depiction of factory chimneys near Paris, capturing the beauty and tension of industrial landscapes.

title: Arrival of the Normandy Train, Gare Saint-Lazare
citation: Impressionist masterpiece showing steam, iron, and glass of the Paris train station — a celebration of modernity.

title: Le Pont Boieldieu à Rouen, Temps Mouillé
citation: Depicts the industrial quays and bridges of Rouen, reflecting the industrialized urban environment.

title: Ironworks Borsig, Berlin
citation: Realistic depiction of the Borsig ironworks in Berlin, emphasizing industrial scale and architecture.

title: The Fighting Temeraire
citation: Symbolic painting of a sailing ship towed by a steam tugboat, representing the end of an era and rise of industrial power.

title: Vitruvian Man
citation: Pen and ink drawing illustrating ideal human proportions based on Vitruvius; Gallerie dell’Accademia, Venice.

title: Design for a Flying Machine (Codex on the Flight of Birds)
citation: Technical sketch showing winged apparatus inspired by bird flight; Turin Royal Library.

title: Studies for the Adoration of the Magi – Perspective and Architecture
citation: Architectural perspective study and human grouping with geometric precision; Uffizi Gallery, Florence.

title: Self-Propelled Cart (Mechanical Vehicle Design)
citation: Early concept of a spring-driven vehicle—sometimes considered a precursor to the automobile; Codex Atlanticus.

title: Design for a Multi-Barreled Cannon
citation: Military engineering drawing showing rotating gun barrels for continuous fire; Codex Atlanticus.

title: Sketches of Hydraulic Machines and Water Lifting Devices
citation: Technical studies of pumps, gears, and water systems; Codex Leicester and Codex Madrid I.

title: The Parachute Design
citation: Cone-shaped parachute concept annotated with dimensional notes; Codex Atlanticus.

title: Studies of Siege Engines and Catapults
citation: Drawings of trebuchets and defensive walls; part of Leonardo’s military engineering commissions for Ludovico Sforza.

title: Mechanical Drawings of Gear Systems and Bearings
citation: Highly detailed mechanical diagrams of pulleys, screws, and cams demonstrating modern engineering principles; Codex Madrid II.

title: Design for a Helical Air Screw (Aerial Screw)
citation: Famous spiral-shaped flying device, an early conceptualization of helicopter flight; Codex B.

title: Flying Machine with Bat Wings
citation: Mechanical study imitating bat anatomy for flight; Codex on the Flight of Birds.

title: „Busti“, Bertoldo
citation: Published in the Italian magazine Bertoldo; early cartoon drawing. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

title: „Arte pura“, Bertoldo
citation: Published in the Italian magazine Bertoldo; example of Steinberg’s early humour. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: „Mobili ultramoderni“ (Ultramodern Furniture), Bertoldo
citation: Cartoon about modern furniture published in Bertoldo. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

title: Panorami di Steinberg
citation: Published in Bertoldo; early panorama drawing. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

title: „Disegno con battuta“ (Gag drawing)
citation: Published in Bertoldo captioned “That’s my husband, he has an inferiority complex.” :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

title: Untitled (Tempera on board)
citation: Tempera on board, 13 ¾ × 9 7/8 in; Estate of Aldo Buzzi. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

title: “But it is half man and half horse”, The New Yorker
citation: Steinberg’s first drawing in The New Yorker magazine. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

title: Strada Palas
citation: Ink, watercolor, and pencil on paper, 14 7/8 × 21 ¾ in; Morgan Library & Museum, New York. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

title: Propaganda drawing (Hitler as a two-faced wolf)
citation: Produced by OSS Morale Operations in Rome during WWII. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

title: Portrait of Bernard Rudofsky
citation: Photostat, 11 ¾ × 8 ¼ in; The Bernard Rudofsky Estate, Vienna. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

title: Untitled
citation: Ink on paper, 14 ¼ × 11 ¼ in; Saul Steinberg Papers, Yale University. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

title: Untitled (1962-64)
citation: Ink, pencil, and watercolor on paper, 22 × 23 in; National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

title: Untitled (New Year’s Eve)
citation: Ink, watercolor, and colored pencil on paper, 14 ½ × 23 in; Cincinnati Art Museum. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

title: Self-Portrait, 1984
citation: Pencil, crayon, and colored pencil on paper, 11 × 14 in; National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

title: Self-Portrait (Marker & crayon), 1984
citation: Marker and crayon on paper, 10½ × 14 in; Blanton Museum of Art, University of Texas at Austin. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

title: Untitled, 1965
citation: Pencil, ink, colored pencil, and collage on paper, 22¼ × 27½ in; Private collection. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

title: Flowers and Ink Bottles, 1985
citation: Watercolor, crayon, colored pencil, charcoal, gouache, pencil and collage on paper, 21¼ × 19 in; National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

title: Las Vegas, 1985
citation: Colored pencil, ink, and pencil on paper, 23⅛ × 29 in; Private collection. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

title: Soho Kiss, 1985
citation: Pencil and crayon on paper, 11 × 14 in; Saul Steinberg Papers, Yale University. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

title: The Doubtful Guest
citation: Short illustrated book by Gorey about a strange penguin-creature arriving at a Victorian household. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

title: The Object-Lesson
citation: Picture book by Gorey: surreal, disorienting, with Victorian/Edwardian settings and sparse narrative. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: The Gashlycrumb Tinies
citation: Gorey’s famous abecedarium of deaths of children ('A is for Amy who fell down the stairs…'). Included in The Vinegar Works set. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

title: The Insect God
citation: One of the trio in The Vinegar Works: a Gothic illustrated narrative of abduction and insects. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

title: The West Wing
citation: Another in The Vinegar Works; numbered sequence of haunting images, no text. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

title: The Iron Tonic: Or, A Winter Afternoon in Lonely Valley
citation: Surrealist country-house mystery in Gorey’s fine-lined engraving style. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

title: The Headless Bust: A Melancholy Meditation on the False Millennium
citation: Late-career Gorey illustrated book, blending dark whimsy and his signature style. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

title: The Unstrung Harp
citation: Gorey’s first book-as-author/illustrator; listed in his bibliography. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

title: The Bug Book
citation: Gorey illustrated book with insect theme (one of his early works). :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

title: The Willowdale Handcar: Or, The Return of the Black Doll
citation: Gorey illustrated tale combining Victorian style and haunted themes. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

title: Where Madness Reigns: The Art of Gris Grimly
citation: Illustrated book by Gris Grimly exploring dark whimsy, monsters, children’s gothic. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

title: The Envious Siblings: And Other Morbid Nursery Rhymes
citation: Illustrated by Landis Blair; heavily cross-hatched drawings, influenced by Gorey. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

title: Matchbook Miniatures
citation: Work by Jason D’Aquino — miniature pen-and-ink drawings on found objects, macabre and detailed; cites Gorey among his influences. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

title: Gothic Blue Book IV: The Folklore Edition
citation: Illustrated by Abigail Larson; dark-fantasy/gothic style, Victorian aesthetic. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

title: Bizenghast Vol. 1
citation: Graphic novel by M. Alice LeGrow with gothic, wood-cut influenced illustration. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

title: The Curious Sofa
citation: Illustrated book by Gorey (pen name Ogdred Weary); satirical, with erotic innuendo through Victorian style illustration. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}

title: The Awdrey-Gore Legacy
citation: One of Gorey’s later titles from his bibliography. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

title: The Dwindling Party
citation: Gorey’s illustrated book blending his macabre narrative and drawing style. (Listed in bibliography) :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}

title: The Utter Zoo
citation: Alphabetic illustrated book by Gorey combining weird animals and Victorian style. :contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}

title: The Black Doll
citation: Gorey-illustrated book listed among his works. :contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}

title: The Gothic Room, “Marble House”
citation: Interior of the Marble House mansion in Newport, Rhode Island featuring ornate plaster ceilings, stained-glass windows and dark wood panelling in the Gothic Revival style.

title: Dining Hall with Pointed‐Arch Windows and Ribbed Vault Ceiling
citation: A dramatic dining room in a gothic-mansion interior showing pointed arch window frames, vaulted ceiling ribs and a deeply shadowed palette.

title: Grand Staircase, “Lyndhurst Mansion”
citation: The staircase in Lyndhurst Mansion, Tarrytown, New York, features narrow halls, sharply arched windows and vaulted ornamentation characteristic of Gothic interiors. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: Hall with Wrought Iron Balustrade and Dark Oak Panelling
citation: Interior hall of a Victorian Gothic mansion in England with dark oak wall panelling, ironwork balustrades and atmospheric volumetric light.

title: Vaulted Salon with Stained Glass and Carved Stonework
citation: Interior of “Treverbyn Vean”, Cornwall — designed by architect William Burges; retains original medieval-inspired interior detailing in a Gothic Revival mansion. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

title: Library with Dark Velvet Draperies and Gothic Furnishings
citation: A mansion-style gothic library space characterised by heavy drapes, carved high-back chairs, dark wood bookshelves and candle-style lighting.

title: Bedroom in Gothic Revival Mansion with Hammerbeam Ceiling
citation: Bedroom in a Gothic Revival mansion showing a hammerbeam ceiling, pointed arch window and richly patterned textile furnishings.

title: Formal Drawing Room with Ribbed Vault Ceiling and Tapestry Wall Coverings
citation: Drawing room of a grand gothic mansion, furnished with tapestry walls, carved mantel, and ceiling ribs painted in a medieval revival palette.

title: Hallway with Stone Floor and Iron Chandeliers in Gothic Mansion
citation: Interior hallway of a gothic mansion featuring stone tile flooring, dark wood panelled walls and wrought iron chandeliers, creating a moody transition space.

title: Conservatory/Orangery in Gothic Style with Vaulted Skylight and Pointed Arches
citation: A glass-roofed conservatory attached to a gothic-mansion home, with pointed-arch window frames, tracery, and wrought iron details typical of Gothic Revival interiors.

title: IKEA Assembly Manuals (Early Pictogram Series)
citation: IKEA flat-pack furniture instruction sheets showing people performing assembly steps

title: Heathkit Electronic Kits – Assembly Guides
citation: Manual pages showing people soldering, wiring, and assembling radio equipment

title: U.S. Army Technical Manual TM 9-803 – Jeep Willys MB
citation: Exploded diagrams and scenes showing mechanics working on Jeep components

title: Volkswagen Beetle – Owner Repair Guide “Idiot Manual”
citation: Famous hand-drawn diagrams showing people fixing and assembling parts

title: Sears Kit Home Assembly Instructions
citation: Assembly sheets showing workers erecting walls, frames, roofs

title: Meccano Construction Set Manuals (Early Human-Figure Editions)
citation: Diagrams showing young builders assembling cranes, bridges, and engines

title: Erector Set Manuals by A.C. Gilbert
citation: Assembly instructions depicting boys and men constructing mechanical models

title: Tonka Metal Construction Toys Assembly Sheets
citation: Manuals sometimes showing people assembling trucks and loaders for demonstration

title: U.S. Navy Seabee Construction Manuals
artist: U.S. Navy Bureau of Yards and Docks
citation: Illustrations showing crews assembling bridges, huts, and heavy equipment

title: FM 5-34 Engineer Field Data Manual
citation: Human-figure diagrams showing assembly of field structures and fortifications

title: Japanese Industrial Safety Assembly Posters (Kamishibai Style)
citation: Sequential illustrations showing workers assembling machinery safely

title: Soviet Technical Manual Illustrations
citation: Manuals depicting workers assembling engines, tractors, and factory equipment

title: General Electric Appliance Installation Manuals
citation: Diagrams with people installing refrigerators, washers, ranges

title: Boeing Aircraft Ground Crew Assembly / Maintenance Guides
citation: Illustrations showing technicians assembling aircraft subcomponents

title: Bridge-building Instructions – Boy Scouts Pioneering Manual
citation: Human-figure diagrams showing rope bridge, tower, and structure assembly

title: Whole Earth Catalog – DIY Structure Assembly Pages
citation: Sketches showing people assembling geodesic domes, tools, structures

title: WWII Aircraft Assembly Line Training Manuals
citation: Diagrams showing workers assembling wings, fuselages, control surfaces

title: Home Workshop Magazine – DIY Furniture Assembly Diagrams
citation: Step-by-step diagrams depicting people building cabinets, tables, tool chests

title: 1960s Construction Equipment Assembly Safety Guides
citation: Manuals showing workers assembling or maintaining heavy equipment

title: Miller Welding Training Manuals
citation: Human-figure diagrams showing assembly of frames, fixtures, steel structures

title: RMS Titanic Cutaway
citation: Published in Illustrated London News; detailed cutaway showing passengers and crew

title: Boeing 747 Cutaway
citation: Created for BOAC promotional materials showing passengers and crew on jumbo jet

title: London Routemaster Bus Cutaway
citation: Double-decker bus illustration showing passengers and conductor

title: Queen Mary Ocean Liner Cutaway
citation: Art Deco promotional cutaway showing people in lounges, dining rooms, and interior spaces

title: Greyhound Scenicruiser Bus Cutaway
citation: Interior illustration featuring passengers and driver of Scenicruiser

title: Lockheed Constellation Cutaway
citation: Aircraft cutaway showing cockpit crew, flight attendants, and passengers

title: Volkswagen Westfalia Camper Cutaway
citation: Iconic camper van interior diagram showing people using the convertible space

title: London Underground Tube Train Cutaway
citation: Cutaway showing commuters, driver, and train internals

title: SS Normandie Cutaway
citation: Detailed ocean liner illustration showing passengers and crew across interior decks

title: NASA Space Shuttle Cutaway
citation: Technical cutaway showing astronauts in crew compartments

title: “View of the World from 9th Avenue”, The New Yorker
citation: Iconic New Yorker cover depicting a Manhattan-centric worldview. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

title: “The Kiss”, The New Yorker
citation: Cover showing an interracial couple kissing, responding to the Crown Heights riots. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: “New Yorkistan”, The New Yorker
citation: Satirical map-style cover reflecting post-9/11 geopolitics. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

title: “Twilight Towers”, The New Yorker
citation: Black-on-black cover commemorating the World Trade Center attacks. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

title: “New York City, 1939”, The New Yorker
citation: Early whimsical cityscape by one of the magazine’s classic cartoonists. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

title: “Spring in Central Park”, The New Yorker
citation: Romanticized seasonal view of Central Park. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

title: “Manhattan Monday”, The New Yorker
citation: Expressionistic depiction of the city’s relentless pace. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

title: “But it is half man and half horse”, The New Yorker
citation: Steinberg’s first drawing in The New Yorker magazine. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

title: “Snowy City”, The New Yorker
citation: Stylized winter portrait of New York streets. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

title: “Under the El”, The New Yorker
citation: Nostalgic illustration of elevated subway life. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

title: “Brooklyn Bridge Centennial”, The New Yorker
citation: Commemorative cover celebrating the bridge’s 100th anniversary. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

title: “Subway Dreams”, The New Yorker
citation: Graphic depiction of subway commuters in motion. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

title: “Manhattan Melting Pot”, The New Yorker
citation: Humorous exaggeration of urban density and diversity. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

title: “Autumn Light”, The New Yorker
citation: Classic seasonal cover by a longtime New Yorker artist. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

title: “Rooftop View”, The New Yorker
citation: Quiet, painterly view of city rooftops. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

title: “Times Square at Night”, The New Yorker
citation: Bold, graphic interpretation of Times Square spectacle. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

title: “Harlem Sunrise”, The New Yorker
citation: Warm, narrative depiction of Harlem in the morning. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

title: “New York Resilience”, The New Yorker
citation: Cover responding to Hurricane Sandy’s impact. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

title: “Sunday in the Park”, The New Yorker
citation: Mid-century social satire set in a city park. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

title: The Tower of Babel
citation: Monumental biblical scene symbolizing human ambition and hubris through architectural excess. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

title: The Hunters in the Snow
citation: Winter landscape emphasizing peasant life, seasonal labor, and atmospheric depth. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: Netherlandish Proverbs
citation: Dense composition illustrating over one hundred Flemish proverbs in visual form. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

title: The Peasant Wedding
citation: Genre scene depicting communal ritual and rural customs with ethnographic detail. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

title: The Triumph of Death
citation: Apocalyptic panorama reflecting late medieval anxieties about mortality and chaos. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

title: Children’s Games
citation: Allegorical overview of childhood play as a mirror of adult folly. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

title: Landscape with the Fall of Icarus
citation: Mythological event subordinated to everyday labor and landscape. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

title: The Census at Bethlehem
citation: Biblical narrative relocated to a contemporary Flemish village setting. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

title: The Adoration of the Magi in the Snow
citation: Fusion of sacred history with winter genre landscape. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

title: The Blind Leading the Blind
citation: Biblical parable rendered as a stark study of human vulnerability. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

title: The Garden of Earthly Delights
citation: Triptych exploring paradise, sin, and damnation through fantastical imagery. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

title: The Haywain Triptych
citation: Moral allegory condemning greed and worldly desire. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

title: The Fight Between Carnival and Lent
citation: Satirical clash between excess and austerity embodied in folk characters. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

title: The Last Judgment
citation: Highly detailed eschatological vision reflecting Northern Renaissance theology. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

title: The Ghent Altarpiece
citation: Polyptych masterpiece uniting naturalism, symbolism, and devotional imagery. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

title: Peasant Dance
citation: Later interpretation of Bruegelian peasant revelry and movement. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

title: The Large Fish Eat the Small
citation: Graphic allegory commenting on power, exploitation, and survival. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

title: The Procession to Calvary
citation: Crowded narrative dissolving sacred drama into mass humanity. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

title: The Conversion of St. Paul
citation: Biblical miracle embedded within a vast Alpine landscape. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

title: The Wayfarer
citation: Symbolic depiction of life as moral journey and perpetual movement. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
